author: sky.cactus
content: <@!187490121698770945> I would like to see a new type of hard fork "soon" where we include code and a fork block for something that will activate in the distant future.  This is specifically valuable for when we want to deprecate certain behavior like the stuff <@273808422753796097> has been talking about.

author: sky.cactus
content: We would go through the normal process, but we would just set the fork block to something like "2 years from now".  The reason for this rather than waiting 2 years and *then* setting a fork block is that it makes it *very* clear to all Ethereum users what features are going away and when.  This is very similar to how enterprise software companies have very clear end of life policies that are announced long in advance.

author: sky.cactus
content: So this isn't "stuff going in to London" but it is stuff that I think we should get scheduled and developed on a similar order of magnitude time frame.

author: gcolvin
content: Deprecation is hard.  For computer languages it can take many years - and source code can be rewritten.  For CPU instruction sets it can take many decades - after 50 years most 8086 code can still run on the latest Intel chips. ("We put the backwards in backwards compatible.")  For blockchains it's close to forever - except for features that are unused or actively harmful.  The Merge really is a sort of one-time opportunity for Ethereum.

author: axic3354
content:
If I understand it correctly, eth2 or the merge doesn't specifically need the precompiles. It needs the functionality to be present in the clients, but exposing it to the EVM is a different question.

Moving funds between validator accounts and eth1 state I imagine could be done via submitting proofs and validating it in the EVM, or could be done natively in the protocol too. In the latter case no need for bls12 in the EVM.

Likewise any kind of other functionality dealing with bls12 on shard data (such as kate commitments), could be done natively.

I think the want for bls12 is for use cases outside of eth2: using pairings for zk constructs.
